global_flags.description: interpret character action codes to be from the specified character set.

)  option.  This  option  supports exactly one device name.

makes  dumpkeys  skip  all  the short-hand heuristics (see keymaps(5)) and output the key bindings in the  canonical  form. First  a  keymaps line describing the currently defined modifier combinations is printed. Then for each key a row with  a  column for  each  modifier  combination is printed. For example, if the current keymap in use uses seven modifiers, every row will  have seven action code columns. This format can be useful for example to programs that post-process the output of dumpkeys.
bind‐ ings and the string definitions.
this  option  is given, dumpkeys prints only the key bind‐ ings. Normally dumpkeys prints both the  key  bindings  and  the string definitions.
action code values to symbolic notation and to print the in hexadecimal format instead.
forces  dumpkeys  to write one line per (modifier,keycode) pair. It prefixes the word plain for plain keycodes.
--console=dev The affected console device can be specified using  the  -C  (or

--charset=charset This  instructs  dumpkeys to interpret character code values ac‐ cording to the specified character set. This  affects  only  the translation  of  character  code values to symbolic names. Valid values for charset currently are iso-8859-X, Where X is a  digit in 1-9.  If no charset is specified, iso-8859-1 is used as a de‐ fault.    This   option   produces   an   output  line  `charset "iso-8859-X"', telling loadkeys how  to  interpret  the  keymap. (For  example,  "division"  is  0xf7  in  iso-8859-1 but 0xba in iso-8859-8.)
